channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy reveals ultrafast molecular dynamics of surface reactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66454-9

Shell-isolated nanoparticle enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS) has enhanced the sensitivity of Raman spectroscopy for applications in materials and life sciences. Here, the authors develop its femtosecond stimulated version (SHINE-FSRS) for in-situ monitoring of molecular dynamics on ultrafast scales.
item.dc:title: Shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy reveals ultrafast molecular dynamics of surface reactions
item.dc:creator: Hong-Gang Sun

item.title: Why covalent organic frameworks grow twisted on graphite
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67598-4

Van der Waals two dimensional materials made of graphene and covalent organic frameworks have potential for advanced electronics applications and a fundamental understanding of the formation process of these materials is desirable. Here, the authors revealed the main aspects that influence the twisted stacking growth of pyrene diboronic acid covalent organic frameworks on graphite with a hybrid molecular mechanics force field.
item.dc:title: Why covalent organic frameworks grow twisted on graphite
item.dc:creator: Veniero Lenzi
Karol Strutyński
Manuel Melle-Franco

item.title: Photoelectrochemical water splitting cells at elevated pressure using BiVO<sub>4</sub> and platinized III-V semiconductor photoelectrodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67294-3

Many hydrogen applications require gas delivered under pressure. Here, the authors report that solar water-splitting devices can operate at up to 8 bar and show that the performance gains from elevated pressure depends critically on the choice of materials and device configuration.
item.dc:title: Photoelectrochemical water splitting cells at elevated pressure using BiVO<sub>4</sub> and platinized III-V semiconductor photoelectrodes
item.dc:creator: Feng Liang
Heejung Kong
Diwakar Suresh Babu
Roel van de Krol
Fatwa F. Abdi

item.title: Thermal responsive Rh<sub>1</sub>-Pd single-atom catalyst for controlling activity in direct formic acid fuel cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66532-y

Thermal protection is critical to extend the service life and avoid overheating in electrochemical devices. Here, the authors report a thermosensitive single-atom Rh1-Pd electrode that enables high activity towards formic acid electrooxidation under 35 °C, which drop down when the temperature is over 35 °C.
item.dc:title: Thermal responsive Rh<sub>1</sub>-Pd single-atom catalyst for controlling activity in direct formic acid fuel cells
item.dc:creator: Keying Su
Shan Yang
Yujia Liang
Dongmei Sun
Mingxing Gong
Yawen Tang
Xiaoyu Qiu

item.title: One-step propylene purification from a quaternary mixture by a single physisorbent
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66438-9

Researchers developed a porous material ZU-921 that solves a key challenge in removing multiple different types of impurities through fine-tuning pore chemistry, enabling the one-step production of high-purity propylene.
item.dc:title: One-step propylene purification from a quaternary mixture by a single physisorbent
item.dc:creator: Peixin Zhang
Zhensong Qiu
Yechen Liu
Sen Chen
Lifeng Yang
Xian Suo
Xili Cui
Huabin Xing
